ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a great deal about the French language, especially grammatical structure and vocabulary.
I learned basic French vocabulary and grammatical structures.
The basic grammar rules of the French language. This course was a great intro for anyone who wants to take college-level French.
I developed a solid foundational understanding of French grammar that I feel will allow me to continue learning. I also enjoyed the opportunity to gain cultural insights about Francophone countries.
I gained a beginner knowledge of the French language.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I think this course is designed pretty well; the units and how they're approached are efficient, even if some of the tests were a bit complicated to understand.

It's taught entirely in French which is both a strength and a weakness. Immersion in the language definitely helps you pick up on sentence structure and vocabulary, but I often found myself translating what the instructor said in French to English, and filling in blanks to make it make sense. The only issue was this made me make false logical assumptions, assuming certain articles meant things they didn't and such.

Classroom participation is encouraged and helps facilitate the learning of French. There is also daily homework in an eTextbook that mostly lines up with what we learn in class. The oral portion of the tests can be difficult at first because the electronic format is not similar to the classroom environment whatsoever.

Strengths: Professor Ngame has a really excellent teaching style and ensure students really understand concepts prior to moving forward. I enjoyed the cadence of the course and the fact that from day one everything was in French

Weaknesses: There was a bit of confusion regarding deliverables and I would have appreciated a more solid syllabus at the start of the semester. Additionally I felt some of the early listening portions of the exam were a bit out of our capabilities that early in the course

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I would. Professor Ngame is a great teacher, and I feel like the course does a good job of making sure students get a thorough hold on French grammar.
Sure, why not. It's a very strong introduction to French. It just simply only applies to those interested in taking French.

I would only recommend this course to someone interested in and committed to learning French at the college level. Even though it is an introductory course, it is difficult compared to some of the other languages offered.
Yes - I took 8 years of Spanish and I feel more confident in French grammar than I do in Spanish grammar just from this one course. It sets you up for confidence as a beginner in the language
If they are interested in quickly picking up French, then yes I would recommend this course.
